Award.AwardTitle: Smooth 4-Manifold Topology, 3-Manifold Group Actions, the Heegaard Tree, and Low Volume Hyperbolic 3-Manifolds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Low-dimensional topology, the study of objects modeled on surfaces (two dimensions), our space (three dimensions), and space-time (four dimensions), is a central area of mathematics of intense contemporary interest. It is at the crossroad of many subfields of mathematics. Methods from combinatorial topology, geometry, minimal surface theory, analysis, group theory, number theory, dynamical systems, and theoretical computer science have contributed to the development of low dimensional topology, and conversely, research in that field stimulates advances in those areas. This research project addresses topics in hyperbolic geometry and foliation theory, which are structures for globally understanding three dimensional spaces, and will also address fundamental questions in smooth 4-dimensional topology. Parts of the research are suitable for undergraduate and beginning graduate student projects. Background material needed for the research as well as new ideas discovered will be incorporated into graduate courses. The award provides funds to support graduate students.

The investigator will continue his approach to the smooth 4-dimensional Schoenflies conjecture through the investigation of knotted three-balls in four-dimensional manifolds and diffeomorphisms of four-dimensional manifolds. He plans to discover new constructions of foliations and laminations and to address the structure of low volume hyperbolic 3-manifolds. The PI and collaborators have discovered new techniques to address these problems and plan to use these methods and discover new ones to make further advances.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The following are summaries of five research works partially supported by the NSF grant.  The PI (with Mehdi Yazdi) proved the fully marked surface theorem: Given a 2-dimensional homology class in a closed hyperbolic 3-manifold whose Thurston norm is induced by the Euler class of a taut foliation, then there is another taut foliation with compact leaves representing that homology class.  Further, the two foliations have homotopic plane fields. The fully marked surface theorem is a converse to Thurston's theorem that compact leaves of taut foliations are norm minimizing.  As an application the PI (with Yazdi) found infinitely many counter examples to Thurston's Euler class-one conjecture, the last remaining open problem from his seminal 1976 paper on the Thurston norm.  These counterexamples relied on a paper of Yazdi based on his Ph. D. thesis written under the PI's supervision.  

The PI initiated the study of homotopy vs isotopy for discs in 4-manifolds with dual spheres, exhibiting phenomena that didn't appear in the 2-sphere setting.  As an application the PI gave the first examples of codimension-1 knotting in 4-manifolds. 

Answering a problem that implicitly goes back to Mazur in the 1960's the PI (with Budney) gave the first examples diffeomorphism of the product of the circle with the 3-sphere that are homotopic but not isotopic to the identity.  They achieved this through a novel construction of diffeomorphisms that can be implanted in any 4-manifold. 

The PI (with Haraway, Meyerhoff, N. Thurston and Yarmola) classified the complete hyperbolic 3-manifolds admitting a maximal cusp of volume at most 2.62. They used this to show that the figure-8 knot complement is the unique 1-cusped hyperbolic 3-manifold with nine or more non-hyperbolic fillings, proving the long-standing Gordon conjecture. 

The PI continued his efforts towards the smooth 4-dimensional Schoenflies conjecture.  As biproducts he proved that a diffeomorphism of a compact 4-manifolds is stably isotopic to the identity if and only if it is pseudo-isotopic to the identity via a pseudo-isotopy with vanishing Hatcher - Wagoner first obstruction.  The PI also introduced the method of "factorization" which the PI (with Gay, Hartman, Krushkal and Powell) used to fix a problem in a fundamental paper of Frank Quinn.

In terms of broader impacts the PI (with Colding and Ketover) wrote an expository paper on geometric methods in Heegaard theory that includes a number of open problems. The PI (with Agol) edited a volume of surveys on the geometry of 3-manifolds.  The PI (with Meyerhoff, N. Thurston and Yarmola) wrote an expository paper on computer experimentation and rigorous computer assisted proofs in the study of Kleinian groups.   The PI co-edited (with Farb and Kerckhoff) three volumes of William Thurston's scientific works which included most of his published and unpublished papers.  These volumes included commentaries on Thurston's contributions to fields such as foliations, hyperbolic geometry, geometric group theory, dynamical systems and theoretical computer science. 

The PI served on the organizing committee of two conferences including the 2023 Princeton RTG Topology Summer School aimed at advanced undergraduates and graduate students.  He served on the advisory board of the Princeton Journal of Undergraduate Research

During the grant period the PI mentored three postdocs, supervised four Ph. D. students of whom two finished and two are current in addition to mentoring a visiting graduate student.  He also supervised two senior theses.  The writer of one won a departmental research prize.  In addition, the PI gave many research and expository lectures at national and international conferences as well as university seminars. These include a four lecture minicourse on surfaces in 4-manifolds at the 2023 Princeton RTG Summer School.


Last Modified: 08/10/2024
Modified by: David Gabai
